turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed by networking—many students find it intimidating, especially when job hunting feels high-stakes. What part of networking feels most challenging to you right now: reaching out to people, knowing what to say, or something else?

A small, manageable step could be setting a goal to connect with just one person from your program or a university alumni group this week. That way, you're building your network in a low-pressure way, which can ease the fear of not finding a job after graduation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, just reaching out feels impossible—I keep worrying I'll say the wrong thing or bother someone.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That's such a common worry—it's totally normal to fear being a bother. Many people with high social anxiety feel the exact same way.

To make it feel less like "bothering" someone, what if your first message was simply asking one specific question about a project they've worked on or their experience with Online University? This frames it as seeking advice, not a demand, and directly helps you build that professional network you want.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Even thinking about sending that message makes my stomach hurt. What if they think my question is stupid or just ignore me?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That fear of rejection is so real—it's a huge source of anxiety for many students, and your feelings are completely valid. It's not a reflection of you or your question being "stupid."

What if you prepared a simple, two-sentence template for your message? For example: "Hi [Name], I'm a fellow Online University CS student. I admired your work on [specific project] and was wondering what your biggest learning was from it?"

Your next step could be to write this message draft without sending it. Just getting the words down is a huge win and makes the action feel smaller and safer.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory, totally get it—"leveraging your network" can sound intimidating. Let’s simplify it. Start small: pick one professor or grad student you admire and ask a specific question after class or via email. For example, "I loved your lecture on algorithms—any advice for undergrads interested in grad school?" This feels genuine, not transactional. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that could work... I just always worry they'll think I'm bothering them or trying to get special treatment.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a common worry, but most educators genuinely want to help engaged students. Remember, asking thoughtful questions shows you’re motivated, not bothersome. Start with one person you feel comfortable approaching—maybe a professor who’s approachable. Keep it brief and specific. You’re not asking for favors; you’re showing interest. That’s how real connections begin.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my brain just goes straight to imagining them rolling their eyes at another eager undergrad. Maybe I'll try my algorithms professor - she did seem nice when I asked about office hours last week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a great choice! Since she was approachable before, build on that positive interaction. Next class, try a simple, specific opener like, “Your office hours advice really helped—could I ask how you decided on your research path?” This keeps it personal and low-pressure. You’re not being “eager,” you’re being engaged. One step at a time—you’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, she did seem genuinely happy to help... I just hope I don't stumble over my words when I ask. Maybe I'll practice what to say a few times first.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart move! Practicing your question a few times will help you feel more confident and natural. Try saying it out loud—maybe in front of a mirror or record yourself. Keep it simple and genuine, just like you planned. You're not trying to be perfect, just prepared. She already responded well before, so trust that positive momentum. You've got this, Gregory!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll try practicing in my dorm tonight... it's just hard to shake that feeling like I'm imposing even when I know logically it's fine.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That feeling is totally normal—many students share it. Remind yourself: professors expect and appreciate student questions. You're not imposing; you're showing initiative. Try pairing your practice with a deep breath before approaching. You're building a skill, not just asking a question. Keep going—you're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: *Takes a deep breath* You're right, I need to remember she literally gets paid to help students. I'll just focus on being clear about why I'm interested in her research specifically.
